title: Brimham Rocks Walk Route

images.title: Elliott Simpson / Brimham Rocks, Nidderdale.
images.caption: Climbers on the rocks. The National Trust site says there is "Rock climbing for the more experienced" - these climbers look very relaxed. The area encompasses both dry and wet heathland, each supporting distinct plant communities. In the dry heathland, visitors can observe species such as wavy hair-grass, bilberry, bell heather, and ling, with occasional oak, rowan, and silver birch trees. The wet heathland areas, characterized by shallow peat soils, are home to plants like wood horsetail, marsh thistle, water blinks, marsh violet, and notable colonies of bog asphodel. Additionally, the site supports uncommon species such as cowberry and chickweed wintergreen.

images.title: Gordon Hatton / 'The Dancing Bear' Brimham Rocks
images.caption: 'The Dancing Bear', Brimham Rocks, in the snow. Several of the rocks at Brimham have fanciful names. Some [like the Idol] are easily spotted, whilst some imagination is required to find the less obvious ones. The names largely date from Victorian times when the rocks became a popular excursion from Harrogate.

images.title: Geertivp, CC BY-SA 4.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/4.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: The rocks known as the turtle and eagle. The fauna at Brimham Rocks is also diverse. The heathland provides habitat for ground-nesting birds, including meadow pipits and red grouse. Raptors such as red kite, buzzard, and kestrel are frequently observed soaring above the rocks. The area also attracts house martins and swallows during the summer months. Mammals like red deer, roe deer, and sika deer inhabit the surrounding moorland. In terms of invertebrates, the heath supports species such as the green hairstreak and holly blue butterflies, as well as the green tiger beetle and the solitary bee Colletes succinctus.

images.title: Sleeping dinosaur - Brimham Rocks by Tom Howard, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Sleeping dinosaur

images.title: David Rogers / Brimham House
images.caption: Brimham House. Now the visitor centre.

images.title: Paul Gillett / Tracks around Brimham Rocks
images.caption: Benches and footpath with a view over Nidderdale from the site.

images.title: Trig Point, Brimham Rocks by Mark Anderson, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Trig Point

description: Brimham Rocks is a National Trust owned site with a collection of fascinating rock formations. You can explore the labyrinth of paths while enjoying fabulous views over Nidderdale. This circular walk starts from the on site car park where you can pick up trails heading around Brimham Moor where there's pretty heather to see. The trails will take you around the ancient rocks which are hundreds of millions of years old. It's also great for wildlife with a number of bird boxes attracting Blue Tits and Redstarts to nest in the area. The site is located near Pateley Bridge and on the Nidderdale Way walking route so there is scope for continuing your walk through the Nidderdale AONB.

details.subtitle: Pubs/Cafes
details.content: There's an on site cafe where you can pick up some refreshments after your exercise.

details.subtitle: Dog Walking
details.content: The site is dog friendly and there are usually plenty of dog owners with their pets. You may need to keep them on leads depending on the time of year and the nesting wildlife.

details.subtitle: Further Information and Other Local Ideas
details.content: Head west from the site along the waymarked Nidderdale Way and you could pick up the Pateley Bridge Circular Walk. This will take you north to the expansive Gouthwaite Reservoir where there is a lovely waterside trail to pick up. For cyclists the epic Way of the Roses and National Cycle Network Route 688 pass through the site. You could follow the signed route from Pateley Bridge to the rocks. Just to the south there's the worthy villages of Summerbridge and Dacre Banks. There's some nice river walks along the River Nidd and a fine 18th century pub to visit in this area. For more walking ideas in the area see the Nidderdale Walks page.

display_address: Brimham Rocks Road, Hartwith cum Winsley, North Yorkshire, York and North Yorkshire, England, HG3 5EY, United Kingdom
